text: Today we have actually the first Q&A
video for 2025. Um, can't believe it's
been this long, but I'm happy to do
these, especially for channel members,
people on Patreon, etc., and for those
on the email list. So, if you want to
participate in this, ask your questions,
please consider becoming a channel
member, joining on Patreon, or getting
on the email list. All links and things
down in the description. Okay, first
question from a channel member, info
channel 392. I'm wondering if you have
explored ways to put yourself out there
as an expert for news organizations to
have on as an interview at appropriate
moments. I think it would be great and I
think this is I think it is needed. We
seem to be in a world in which debunking
is needed almost every day. I agree. Um
I have listed myself on a couple of
those websites that reporters use but it
seems to be not very useful. Um, there
are moments when I do reach out to news
organizations, usually because I'm going
to debunk them in some way and I want to
just reach out and maybe have a
conversation beforehand, but none of
that has really led to that. I do think
this is something I would like to do
because just having a datadriven
perspective, not to say I'm an expert
really here, but I am able to look at
the data and bring it to the
conversation. Hopefully, that would be
helpful and interesting for them. From
Morigard on YouTube, is it worth
replacing the battery on an older Nissan
Leaf? I've seen videos recently from a
Chinese company that is making new
batteries for Gen One Leafs. Uh don't
know if it actually makes sense. I mean,
some of these batteries are still fine
and they do the job if you want longer
range or something like that. It's
something cool and worth exploring.
There are companies here in the US that
do that. I know um of EV West up in
Vista, not too far from where I'm at.
And what they do is they'll even take
like old Tesla batteries and kind of
retrofit them into there. So, it is
something that is possible. If you could
do that and retool it and get like 400
miles of range, I think that'd be
awesome because you'd probably do it for
pretty cheap. I don't know anything
specifically about a Chinese company
that's doing it though. We have two
questions here. Starting with one from
Wordsfish Trombone. Who will take the EV
reigns after, you know, and from Mr.
Ryan Schneider, who I did meet in
person. Hello, Ryan. Thanks for
commenting here. Um, do the
manufacturers in the UAW stand a chance?
So, generally speaking, what's going to
happen to Tesla? Is Elon going to leave
them? Is he going to refocus? Is that
going to help the political situation?
And the people that are really upset
about that? I mean, it's a tough one to
see how far this goes. The people that
are upset and don't want to be
associated with him seem to be ever
growing at this moment, and I don't know
if that's going to slow down or change.
Uber comes to mind, how they ended up
having to sack their CEO and save the
company. And essentially, it worked. you
know, Uber is pretty popular now and not
many people nowadays really remember uh
his name or what that was about. Elon is
maybe a little bit different in that
situation. Um I would like to see
someone that is squarely focused on
making great electric vehicles and
innovating in that space. That to me has
always been where Tesla shined. a lot of
the other ancillary stuff that they're
doing, which some people, especially
people that have large stockholdings,
would argue is the main thing they're
doing. Maybe to me that's just, you
know, not as useful of an endeavor and
they could do something better with
those resources. So, uh, do the
manufacturer at the UAW stand a chance?
I don't know. Um, it's really weird
what's happening in that space. I think
unions are pretty strong though and they
have a lot of people on their side and a
lot of politicians on their side. So I
think the auto workers and the other big
unions out there do have a lot of power.
So you know it's going to be an
interesting battle to see how this plays
out over the next four years. From
Graham, given that Robo Taxi is on the
verge of starting up, what are your
thoughts on the media push back that
Tesla does not have a customer base for
this service? Is this slow to start or
is it an instant success? This is an
interesting one. Um I and for people
that know me and have been followers of
the channel for a long time, they'd know
I'm pretty skeptical about the whole
robo taxi idea. Not that it's not
possible. I mean, Whimo was out there
doing what 100,000 rides per week
entirely autonomously. Like they have
backup drivers and monitors, but nobody
physically in the car. And they've been
doing that for years now. I mean,
they're in many different big cities,
LA, San Francisco, um Chandler, Phoenix,
I know, and a bunch of others I'm sure
I'm missing. But this tech will work. Um
the the economics are the challenge.
Tesla's version of it being vision only.
Um I I don't know how long it's going to
be before that's really good. I just saw
today on the news or on my my daily EV
podcast there was a story about I think
10 or 12 cars are all they're going to
start with and they're going to have
drivers in them and everything. So um
it's going to be a slow start for Tesla
for sure. How long until they get there
and is it going to become some giant
business? I think the bigger hurdle is
people trusting autonomous vehicles
period. Uh then you have the problem of
Tesla and its association with Elon
because a lot of people may be open to
self-driving cars or robo taxis but they
don't want to be associated with him or
take that. Now if you can get a ride
from the airport for $2 when normally it
costs 50, I think you would win. But
anytime I've looked at the economics of
robo taxis, it seems like pretty much a
losing bet at this point. Insurance
requirements, maintenance on the
vehicles, cost of the vehicles, all
those things, uh, make it to where from
every way I've looked at it, it's not
going to be this, you know, panacea that
maybe some people think it is. So, slow
start for sure. Will it ever succeed?
Sure. Is Tesla going to be the ones to
do that? Or is it going to be Whimo
who's already, you know, miles and miles
ahead? Who knows? But my bet right now
is that with Tesla, it's going to be a
very slow roll out. From Ivon Nowell,
what is the difference between PHEV and
EREV or E-Rev? Are there any - available
in the United States? So, uh, PHEV is a
plug-in hybrid electric vehicle.
Essentially, it's a gas car with a large
battery that will give it, you know, 20,
30, maybe 40 miles of range on electric
only. And they're pretty good, actually.
I think a lot of people that have them
start to open up and soften to the idea
of going fully electric. So, I I'm a fan
of them in that regard. Then you have
the flip side of that, which is the
E-Rev, the extended range electric
vehicle. This is where you instead of
having a gas car with a battery, you
have an electric car with a gas
generator. That gas generator can add
miles. In the US, the only one I'm aware
of that is coming out is one of these,
or I think both Scout options, the truck
and the SUV. And there, it's interesting
because I believe the battery alone will
get over 300 mi of range. And then the
gas generator will add an extra 100 or
so miles. And I don't know how many
gallons of gas it requires, but I do
think that that is an interesting play
and an interesting approach. If they if
you had an E-Rev that had 300 plus miles
of range and then the occasional time
where you would might want that extra uh
gas backup, I could see that being
useful. A lot of e-revs, specifically
the ones I know of from Lee Auto in
China, they don't have the 300 mile
range. have 130 mi of range, which is
still almost all of it for most people
on a day-to-day basis. But that to me is
where, you know, there's sort of this
weird balance. And in both situations,
you end up where uh they are sort of the
the best and worst cases for both
situations, right? So the complexity of
these things is very very high. Uh so
defects and and repairs and all those
things are much higher in PHEVs compared
to regular BEVs or even gas cars. So,
it's one of those things where I like
the idea mostly as a gateway drug, but
if they did it right, I think there
could be a market for it. Taigo Arantes,
I don't know if that's how you say your
name, but that's what I'm going with.
What are your thoughts on all of the new
EV initiatives popping up in 2025? T
Slate and how current economic
challenges may affect their success.
Well, this is an interesting one. Um, TE
is the little tiny truck thing that's
pretty cool looking. I haven't got to
see it in person. Has a gear tunnel and
and all that. I like the idea. It's
actually I think very cool. Um and Slate
is the modular one that's you know
relatively cheap and you can configure
it a bunch of different ways. Has like
you know rollup windows and things like
that. So I like the idea. I really think
this is cool. I mean basically in my
head the more the marrier. uh the more
ways that we can fulfill our
transportation needs that with electric,
you know, propulsion, the better we're
all going to be uh for a multitude of
reasons, obviously. Um but, you know, TE
specifically is cool. I could see like
delivery services doing that kind of
thing. Slate, I think, is again cool.
Maybe you have a a company that wants a
specific vehicle and they can make it
themselves and add on and stuff. I think
it's pretty cool. I I I'm I'm stoked on
all of these things and I just think
generally the more the marrier. I'm
happy once we have more unique options
out there like these
two. John Bergster asked, "Do you see
the trend towards popularity of PHEV
vehicles as a permanent situation or
more of a bridge to convert more to the
electric concept and ultimately to bev
vehicles in the future?" Well, this is
kind of what I was talking about earlier
and I I think that it's a it's a gateway
drug. Absolutely. Like I can tell you
several friends had a Chevy Volt which
was one of the earlier PHVs here in the
US and they would get gas you know two
three times a year and that really
opened up their eyes to like wow this 40
mile range or 30 mile range whatever it
had is almost enough. I mean 300 miles
of range gez that's like plenty. I never
need more than that. So I think it is a
gateway drug. I don't think it's a
permanent solution or permanent
situation because PHEVs have a lot of
problems and you know if you look at the
maintenance costs and and the repairs
and you know fire risk and all these
other things PHVs tend to always be the
worst case scenario. So I do think that
the opposite of that the ERV or the
E-Rev could be a more lasting situation
but again it introduces a lot of
complexity to the vehicle itself which
means you as the consumer the owner have
to deal with that. Plus, it introduces
complexity to the manufacturing process,
which means cost and then repairs and
everything else. So, I don't know. Um, I
we're absolutely going towards a fully
electric future. I see this absolutely
as more of a bridge to that. Um, and it
may not even be that big of a bridge
because the way that EVs are advancing
already, bevs are are are advancing now,
we're pretty much knocking down any last
kind of concerns people have, even if
those are just more perception than
reality. Edgardo asks, "What is the most
difficult thing you have encountered
moving to electric car and solar
powerhouse?" I think the most difficult
thing is navigating the time of use
rates with my electric company.
Thankfully, I have Franklin batteries
and they have a way to just
automatically help me offset that. So
once you get solar and batteries with
Franklin anyways, you literally just say
here's my my electricity plan and it
will automatically make sure that you're
maximizing savings or you know go living
off-rid self- consumption whatever. So I
would say that's probably the most
confusing difficult part. Um if you
don't have a place to charge at night I
would say that can add a lot of
complexity depending where you live. Um
even here in Southern California where I
live, you know, that still can be a
challenge depending on what neighborhood
you're in and all that. So I think um
you know just some infrastructure things
and then more of the like the pricing
around electricity is sort of confusing
and difficult to navigate right now.
Paul Summers asks, "Many of my friends
still have range anxiety about EVs. Have
you looked at the charging
infrastructure to determine if there are
any places that are not being serviced
adequately for domestic travel?" I
haven't dove too deep into this. Very
aware that there are lots of places
where it is more difficult in terms of
road trips. I would say if you here
here's kind of the way it works in my
head. Um if you live somewhere that has
a lot of public charging like say
Southern California, you pretty much are
good to go. Doesn't matter what your
situation. It's it's totally doable.
Maybe slightly less convenient than
owning a gas car, but you know, you make
for it up in savings and everything
else. Then if you're in certain, let's
say, rural parts of the country, let's
say West Texas or somewhere like that,
travel through there might be difficult.
However, on a day-to-day basis, you're
going to be saving a lot of money
because you're charging up at home. So,
if you can charge up at home in a place
that doesn't have a lot of public
infrastructure, totally fine. Um Hank
Green comes to mind, who lives, if I
understand, in Missoula, Montana, um
which does actually have a couple
superchargers nearby, but is, you know,
not uh Los Angeles, let's say, and he's
able to get get by fine because he has a
house with a garage. So, it's one of
those things where I think it's it's
it's a there's no one simple answer to
this question. Uh, obviously, there's
lots of money flowing into this space
and companies are building up uh mini
chargers, you know, every year. I mean,
I think we're adding a thousand new
public chargers a week during Biden's
term. So, I don't know where it's at
now, but um it'll be a problem that's
basically solved. And it's so much
easier of a problem to solve than they
had to solve initially with gas cars
because, you know, unlike gas and
gasoline, um you don't have to truck in
electricity. Electricity is already
there. We have a nationwide grid or a
couple of different grids that make up
the nationwide grid. And so you just
have to tap into it and make sure that
things are right. But it's already
there. So it's a much simpler, easier
thing to handle. And I think in the
coming years, it won't even be something
to talk about. Greg asks, "If solid
state batteries are the holy grail, why
isn't there an absolute fullcourt press
to make them reality? Co happened and a
vaccine was developed quick, fast, and
in a hurry. I know it's apples to
oranges, but why the foot dragging?" I
would argue that they're not dragging
their feet here. Um, I think it's, you
know, the solid state battery and also
maybe it isn't the holy grail. I mean in
some cases it will absolutely uh give us
you know lower cost more safety uh
higher capacity and quicker charging.
Yes, like it it solves all of the
concerns. However, if you're seeing what
BYYD has done recently with their sodium
ion batteries and some of the other
technologies out there that are
happening where they're charging
literally 200 plus miles of range added
in five minutes with over a megawatt
speeds. I mean we're kind of already
there, you know. So solid state I think
um is a promising future but I don't
think that we need to wait on it. And I
mean I I would venture a guess that you
know the companies I think um is it is
it Samsung or there's a few companies
that have announced they have a working
solid state battery. So I think they're
going to be here fairly soon but I also
don't know if we need them or if they're
going to you know be the solution or the
the holy grail as you say that many
think they are. Al asks, "Given the
growth trend in EVs globally, what are
the factors you see contributing to
lower numbers in the US versus global
numbers? Why are those factors gaining
traction here?" Well, this is, I think,
largely a political one, and I've talked
about it here on the show, where the
idea is simply this. Um, the world is
electrifying. It is going very, very
quickly towards fully electric modes of
transportation. And that's led by
Chinese companies, you know, BYD, Gile,
which owns a bunch of other ones and
everything. Um, yeah, that that's where
it's headed, right? If you think about,
let's say, Australia, Southeast Asia,
Latin America, they don't make a lot of
cars in these places. Some don't make
any at all. And they import almost all
of them. So, because of that, there are
no import tariffs or anything like that
preventing uh China from flooding those
markets. And as such, they are selling
very competent, good products at a very
compelling price. Now, we could argue
about how they get that price and this
and that, but the point is is that as a
to a consumer, it's just going to be the
best option, right? It doesn't matter
that it's electric. It's just cheapest
and best. And so, I'm in. And that is a
big chunk of the world. Even in Europe,
you know, where they are do have import
taxes on some of these Chinese EVs
coming out, um, they still are are
proliferating everywhere throughout
Europe. So it's one of those things
where yeah the world is very different
and then in the US we have absolutely a
very strong protectionist strategy
because our auto industry is very
sensitive and so my problem is that by
having a protectionist strategy having
huge tariffs on them to essentially
block out uh Chinese EVs and everything
like that and pushing for actual uh less
fuel efficient gas cars which is what
the current administration's doing,
you're actually hurting US automakers
because are going to disincentivize them
from innovating. And so they're going to
be further and further behind all of
these the rest of the world essentially
to the point where that could kind of be
the end for them maybe 101 15 years down
the road because they are just falling
further and further behind. This is why
some of those automakers, I think all
the big three in the US, uh, lobbyed
for, uh, the administration currently to
keep all of these standards because it
would, they've already made huge
investments towards this goal and then
now they're sort of having to walk back
on them and lose all that money just to
what in a couple years restart them all.
So, it's one of those things the the uh,
instability and the flip-flopping nature
of the politics here in the US I think
are causing real harm or you know,
starting to see some of those cracks. uh
in the US auto industry and hopefully it
doesn't lead to an absolute demise of
it, but it it could spell doom in the
future. Stephen CPPley asks, "Will solar
PV sales and other solar equipment be
made in the US in the near future? With
tariff uncertainty, I'm hesitant to buy
from China at the moment. Is it likely
for the US to create PVs here with
requisite profit? Thanks, Ben. Love your
insights." Well, thanks Stephen. Um I
don't know that I have a ton of insights
here. I this this is one of those things
where you know if you look at the the
raw materials and where those things are
being uh handled you know where they're
being refined and processed into metals
that we need for solar cells for
batteries all this it's all coming from
China and even if you start to move it
to the to and even if you start to move
it to the US you're going to have to pay
you know something like a multiple
factor increase in cost whereas the rest
of the world isn't. And so I think that
is sort of a fool's errand. I mean,
globalization is something that I think
has benefited a lot of people. Yes,
there are times where we have unfair
trade practices and maybe import taxes
and things are are the right answer. I'm
not, you know, that educated as an
economist in that regard, but I mean,
even as from the time you probably asked
this question to the time I'm recording
this, there's a 90-day tariff pause and
actually a reduction in overall tariffs
from products coming from China. Um,
China makes, you know, good products.
Uh, you know, you could argue lots of
different ways around that, but because
of the cost alone, I don't see it
changing anytime soon. Um, and if
anything, down the down the road, it's
just going to probably increase. So, I
wouldn't have any hesitation to buy
things from China right now. Uh, if
they're already here on on on our shores
or they're within this 90-day window.
Um, but yeah, I don't see it really
shifting that
dramatically focused on the US. I think
it's going to stay in China for as long
as you know we're making these kind of
things. Ken aka Tesla Ken on the forums
asks, "For years I've seen articles
almost daily about some new battery
chemistry, some new battery packaging,
some new battery charging rate, etc.
that is going to revolutionize the
battery industry. If you went back, say
5 or 10 years, and looked at the promise
of what was coming, how did those
promises compare to what was actually
delivered?" Thanks, Ken. Um, yeah, it's
an interesting question. And I mean
that's the difference between a
discovery in a lab and the
productionization right the the
mechanization of of of that thing making
it in a factory where it's durable
passes safety checks and all that. Uh we
are seeing lots of things happening in
this space. I mean look at what Bid is
doing with their blade battery and the
sodium ion ones that that actually love
the cold. They work you know really
exceptionally well in extremely cold
temperatures. I mean there's a lot of
money pouring into this and it really
Yeah. I guess EVs are one way that that
they manifest, but also, you know,
cameras, phones, iPads, computers,
whatever. Everything around uses
batteries pretty much in one way or
another. So, this is, you know,
multi-trillion dollar industry. And that
of course includes EVs, but EVs are not
the sole thing that uses batteries here.
Maybe EVs are slower to adopt some of
these because of the challenges with
like being in a car, but we're seeing
some tremendous things already. So, I
don't know. I I mean, I bet if you fast
forward 5, 10 years from now, you'll see
some it'll be night and day versus what
we have today. But the nature of a
battery still sort of works the same
way, right? You have an anode and a
cathode and a separator and, you know,
one one side holds the charge and then
it, you know, it passes it onto the
other side. So, the concept is basically
the same. Um, so I don't know if there's
anything any major changes to that, but
how we do it I think is just
incrementally getting better. So after a
decade, yeah, it'll look unrecognizable.
Doug Kerry asks, "Can the EV
manufacturer standardize on a knack
charger port location? On a recent trip,
a Ford Lightning and a Kia or Hyundai,
not sure which, were charging at
superchargers, but both were using two
spots." Yeah, there's some answer to
this. I don't know. Yeah, they are
changing locations. Like the Rivian R2,
I know they switched where it was going
to be to match where it is on a Tesla,
so that way it works better. and they're
going to have the next port, so it'll
basically work the same. Um, yeah, right
now we're sort of in that transition
period. You know, Tesla opened it up
recently after the the government money
or funding was sent their way so they
could actually allow other supercharger
or other networks on there. Um, and
yeah, it's a challenge right now. I
agree. Uh, really I find this only to be
a challenge though in more densely
populated areas. So, if you're in LA,
yeah, you may be having to deal with
this more. But if you're out in Barstow
or traveling, you know, across the
desert, Bakersfield, somewhere like
that, a smaller town, smaller city, then
I don't I don't think it's a big deal
because these chargers are largely
empty. So, and that's from personal
experience, you know, as a Rivian owner
doing this on multiple road trips across
deserts from here to Las Vegas, from
here up the coast to Carmel, from here
out to Arizona and back. I mean, I've
done a lot of trips in this case and,
you know, it it really only is an issue
where you're in a densely populated
area. So, I hope they standardize on it.
I know that some are. Um, but also the
new V4 chargers have, I think, 14 foot
long cables. So, you know, there could
be an extension cord in the future. I
don't know. I don't think it'll be a
problem, which is sort of this in
between land right now. John Dwan, John
Dwan, John Dan, uh, many Tesla owners
are moving away from Tesla because of
Elon. I love my Tesla Model Y and
especially the self-driving, which I use
90% of the time, including city streets.
Are there any other EVs with
self-driving that approaches Tesla? If
so, which ones? I'm hoping Rivian gets
there. Sorry to say, John, no. Uh, no
one that I've tested, and I've tested, I
think all of them at this point are
anywhere close to Tesla. In terms of
that driver assist feature that you're
talking about in terms of the actual
self-driving nature where you like
wouldn't have a person driving, yeah,
Whimo is is far ahead of them.
Obviously, 100,000 miles or 100,000
trips per week that they're booking in
many cities across the US. Yeah. Um, so
in terms of the autonomous driving,
Tesla is actually far behind. But in
terms of what you're talking about where
you have a driver assist that's very
good, yet no one even comes close. I
mean, I just had an argument with
somebody the other day about this about
Rivian where I've tested them all. I
have a Rivian R1T Gen 1 and it's
basically unusable. The driver plus
feature, I do not trust it whatsoever.
Even the just the basic uh the basic um
speed up, slow down, cruise control, I
don't trust. uh whereas you know a 2018
Tesla is like light years ahead of even
the Gen 2 Rivians today. I hope they do
get there. There actually are some open-
source options. Uh I saw Quinn over at
Snazzy Labs do an interesting one with
his Rivian where he was able to set it
up. So it was this open source software
that was controlling it and it was
actually performing better than Rivian's
own. I know they're investing a lot in
this but I don't know if anyone will
catch Tesla from the driver assist
standpoint for the next I don't know
five six years. Ron asks, "Where do you
think the EV market is going in the USA?
Also, sustainable energy." Well, it's a
big question. I'll try to keep it short
here. I think the EV market in the US is
being depressed by the policies of the
current administration and the
protectionist strategies as well. Uh,
we'll see where that goes. Now that
there's a tariff pause with China, does
that mean that the Chinese EVs no longer
have a 100% tariff? They only have the
30% or whatever it is. If so, we could
see an absolute flood of Chinese EVs
into the market. There'd be backlash. I
don't know. So, because of the political
situation here in the US, I I think EVs
are going to be slower adoption than the
rest of the world by far. Sustainable
energy is a different one. There's a lot
of jobs on the line. In fact, a lot of
senators and stuff are pushing back
because the latest budget bill that I
saw for Congress, they were going to
basically gut the inflation reduction
act that Biden passed and in doing so
cut, you know, potentially hundreds of
thousands of jobs in a lot of these red
states who are the people in power now
that are going to be voting for that.
So, they're sort of voting against their
own citizens best interest. So, I don't
know. Sustainable energy might have a
better chance. EVs, unless something
happens, I think are going to be a
slower adoption rate here in the US um
than other parts of the world, which
again puts the US at a disadvantage.
Bogart asks, can you make Daily Charge
up into a video or is it not worth the
hassle? Well, thanks for the question
and thanks for listening. So, Daily
Chargeup is my daily podcast which is
all about EV news. It's me picking
stories. It's my writer making sense of
them and we have cloned my voice. So, we
use AI to sort of make the bread. Um,
but you know what actually goes into
that is all human driven. So, we have a
sort of human AI collaboration. Some
people have a hard time with it, but a
